column1: もう一時間{{c1::目::1st}}が{{c2::始まっていました::had started}}。
column2: The first period had already started.
column5:
**一時間** [2] / **始まる** [0].
1. 〜目: Suffix to turn counters into ordinals (1st, 2nd, etc.).
2. 〜ていた: Here it describes a state that resulted from a past action (the period started and was ongoing).

column1: 教室に{{c1::入ると::when [someone] entered}}先生がレオ君に言いました。
column2: When (someone) entered the classroom, the teacher spoke to Leo.
column5: **入る** [1]. This 〜と indicates that the second action (the teacher speaking) happened immediately after the first action (entering).

column1: お母さんが{{c1::起こしてくれなかった::didn't wake me up}}んです。
column2: It's because my mother didn't wake me up.
column5: **起こす** [2]. Transitive: to wake someone up. 〜てくれる shows the action was expected as a favor. 〜んです indicates the speaker is providing an explanation or excuse.

column1: レオ君が{{c1::泣きながら::while crying}}走りました。
column5: **泣く** [0]. The action mentioned after ながら (in this case, running) is the primary focus.

column1: 遅刻しないで、学校へ{{c1::来なさい::come (command)}}。
column2: Don't be late; come to school.
column5: **来る** [1]. 〜なさい is a firm command used by people in authority (teachers, parents). It is attached to the masu-stem of verbs.

column1: レオ君、早く寝て、早く{{c1::起きなければなりません::must}}。
column2: Leo, you must go to bed early and wake up early.
column5: **起きる** [2]. Formal obligation. Note: なきゃいけない is more common in casual speech.
